Sir: A long and Distressing lines. ha. prevented
me from repyipg to your letter oi the 9th u,lmo.

would discussion have been admitted thereon,
a, II es entirely cut OF the con pe,ency of the Cen
erai Government. In ahxlously wishing to embrace
all the land within the limits OF Georgia every ef.
lo,t was made to induce them 10 agree 10 a clause
TO that elect, In so many words. They ptrempto.
ry refused on The ground OF their ignorance Of the
direction Of that line Had the dividing line between

mighty probable, that We should have succeeded in

ne controversy between Georgia and Alabama, your

d'thculy 70 an entire cession continues to impede

we'd will be the one whio h the Executive will EN-.

nave the honor TO be, sir, your obedent serl'h

silly sentence, must have smiled at is folly Sup
pose the Ge'e al Government confines itself in The
exercise Of power, the letter Of the constitution
without regarding its spi'if.or II. end pi all gos
?rnmental ihstitulions,-uhat would he its power,
what It's utility Nothing, literally nalhing. The
power expressly delegated by the letter OF the con
stituton, would enable Congress TO involve the ma
ton in war, but not to prosecute il with effect or
bring US oh OF i; 10 lay and collect duties and axes
to an unlimited extent, bui no. 10 use The money !;
(for il is as Unconstitutional TO divide the surplus
and oansls With it-neither being mentioned, in
terms IN the constitution y sppoin, Ministers to
negotiate treaties but not 10 carry the treaties into
operation. Happily isr coun.ry and its pros.
perity, the men who have composed The General
Government have taken the spirit OF the constu.
ton Tor their guide, end the good and glory Of their
country Tor Their object in their exercise Of power
and, happily Tor them, they have been borne out ia
SO doing by the people. But the sentiment express
sed by DE Wit Clinton, that he could s'perceve
nothing less than certain DESTRUCTION 10 the State
Governments in the exercise by the General Gov
ernment OF the power OF constructing roads aud
canals, is at war even with his own works. There

The following paragraph IS translation from PEtoit
Paris paper OF Octuter last, and We present ito tic
public as record Of remarkable IN this eh ghR
ed age. Ii refers 10 lieu,. j. WAsHiscToN, distant
relative OF Gen Washington, sho Wert tc Greece some
eighteen months ago. uIdei the patronage Il The Glct
Committee Of tins Cny. Afer Lieut. Washing on lal
engaged TO 60 10 Greece, tile Committee had reason 10
doubt whether he had all the sincerity ard dei oton Ne
cause Which lie prutessed. He was highly recon mtnd,t
in letters dated indeed two years previously iron Press


dent Mo ROE, Mr.. An,rs, then Secretary OF state, aud
Others, which induced the Committee TO assist him IN Lis
voyage 10 Greece.


I. A young American, Of an ilusrious name, who de-
,inguisAed himself West Poln', by his mathematcs
knoS dre, has just abured Protestaniism ana elefel
INTO the bosom ot Tie church. Mr.. Washington, native
o the United States, ou lie aye Of 25, to Europe
10 embrace the t the Greeks he papers OF the
tine announced his devotion to their service he passed
time ir Greece, afterwards left that COUNT! pro
baby account Of the misunderstanding s and d'isoni
which lie observed among the chiefs.


Having arrived Al PARIS, lie took occasion to acqnar
himself With the Catholic religion, which he had otl
known according the ptcjud.ces prevalent among PrC
lio and reflection which important subject deserve,
ani having disco, cree, the truth, lie has embraced VIII
generous adour His abjula ion preceded by re
nrement Of eight days 1t took place - the cha'eao
Tue Duke OF Rohau. and received BY the Bishop q
strasburg That preate administered the communion and
the sacrament Of confirmation to the young stranger, VIII
ediad the spectators BY bis pety, his eryor, and L
strength OF his isth'

10 aid in constructing roads and canals, than De

full articles.article:
DEPARTMENT OF WAR,


eth .tor. 1896.
Sir: A long and Distressing lines. ha. prevented
me from repyipg to your letter oi the 9th u,lmo.
Since my partial recovery have su mittrd il 10
the President, by whom am instructed 10 say tha,
you appear 10 latour under most serious mistake
~ supposing that the last treaty with the Greeks
has affected in any msnnet the boundary oi Georgia.
There IS not title IN the treaty that has The most
distant allusiom 10 that object nor for one momen.
would discussion have been admitted thereon,
a, II es entirely cut OF the con pe,ency of the Cen
erai Government. In ahxlously wishing to embrace
all the land within the limits OF Georgia every ef.
lo,t was made to induce them 10 agree 10 a clause
TO that elect, In so many words. They ptrempto.
ry refused on The ground OF their ignorance Of the
direction Of that line Had the dividing line between
Georgia and Alabama been established, think il
mighty probable, that We should have succeeded in
obtaining their renqushmtnt; he more especisl.
!! as perceive that even by the line run by the
''eoIela commissioners, 10 which is under stood,
uhothclally. the Aahana Commissioners dissented,
there ~ less Than 100000 acres OF Indian Lands.
IL is Mslter OF regret tha, aty cifheu,iy should
nave occurred between Georgia and A ALBANIA in fi1-
ing Their dividing line as The President had de sign
CO. me moment the line had bern established, 10 o.
pen iresh negotiations with the Greeks Tor the pur.
pose OF procuring any fragment OF land such line
might have lei, OF theirs within the limit. Of cor.
sla. Without entering at all into the merits Of
ne controversy between Georgia and Alabama, your
Excellency must at once perceive thar the original
d'thculy 70 an entire cession continues to impede
our course, and the first instant that shall be reno.
we'd will be the one whio h the Executive will EN-.
brace TO carry into effect, by fresh negotiation,
practicable, the entire cession.


nave the honor TO be, sir, your obedent serl'h


JAMES BARBOUR.


His Exctllency Geo M Troup,


Governor Of Gscrga

since by that am accused Of ambition and an al
